NewsLine.NewsLineText: IRELAND-MCCREEVY:Irish finance minister resists calls to quit

body.p: By Kevin Smith

DUBLIN, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Irish Finance Minister Charlie McCreevy refused to resign on Monday after he was accused of deceiving voters about Ireland's public finances in the run-up to May's general election.

Opposition parties demanded McCreevy's head after a leaked memo allegedly showed the government knew early this year that spending cuts would be required but took no action until it had been returned to power.
A finance department spokesman told Reuters the minister had no intention of stepping down.
"McCreevy will not be resigning -- there's no question of it," the spokesman said.
He would not comment on the content of the memo but said an immediate probe had been launched into how it came to be published by an Irish Sunday newspaper.
The confidential document distributed to ministers in June paints a grim picture of potential risks to the economy and calls for public spending cuts of 900 million euros next year.

The Sunday Tribune said the memo, and other documents obtained by the newspaper, showed McCreevy knew as far back as January that cuts would be needed but government departments continued to spend freely ahead of the election.
Since returning to power, the centre-right government has already made a series of what it calls "adjustments" to spending, sparking widespread public anger.
In a pre-election pledge McCreevy told voters: "I can confirm there are no significant overruns projected and no cutbacks whatsoever are being planned, secretly or otherwise."
SHARP SLOWDOWN

Deputy leader of the Labour Party, Brendan Howlin, said the finance minister had now lost all credibility. "At a time of more difficult economic circumstances, a finance minister without credibility or authority is a luxury the country cannot afford," he said.
"McCreevy should accept responsibility for this shocking con-job and go."
Main opposition party Fine Gael accused the government of "deception on a massive scale" and also urged McCreevy to go.
After more than five years of unprecedented boom the Irish economy has slowed sharply, with growth forecasts slashed to less than five percent from average annual rates of 10 percent.
With tax revenues dwindling, the memo proposes swingeing cuts to environment, education and social welfare spending. Health, already chopped back this year, would be further hit.
Hefty hikes in excise duties on "old reliables" such as cigarettes, petrol and beer are also proposed.
McCreevy, who will present his next budget on December 4, was booed by members of a live television audience when he appeared on a popular Irish chat show at the weekend.
Growing public disllusionment with the government over the fading economy has recently prompted fears of a backlash vote in next month's referendum on the EU's Nice Treaty.
Irish voters shocked Europe last year by rejecting the document, which is crucial to plans for enlarging the 15-state bloc by up to 10 new members. A second ballot is scheduled for October 19.
